document.title: Intellisense and Completion
document.paragraph:
The EiffelEnvision editor comes complete with all vcovrAutomaticStatementCompletion 0 features expected of a Visual Studio .NET editor.
code_completion
2 List Members and Complete Word
Code completions is based on the vxurfCodeTextEditorWindow 0 core Visual Studio .NET editor 's vcgrfListMembers 0 list members feature. It provides the ability to list and complete Eiffel /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml feature *features and /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *class names. By default the editor will automatically display the vcgrfListMembers 0 list members window when typing a '.' (period) when qualifying feature calls. The list members window may not appear all of the time. You may have incorrectly spelt a client feature name (prior to the period), there are no features currently /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml feature *exported to the client or the information may not be available at that time and a compilation is required.
The list members may also been shown by at any time using CTRL+SPACEBAR or ALT+RIGHT ARROW.
If you have already begun to type a feature's name you may access the vcgrfCompleteWord 0 Complete Word functionality of the editor. Complete word does not require a qualified feature call as does vcgrfListMembers 0 list members . As long a a single character has been typed you may complete that feature. Pressing CTRL+SPACEBAR or ALT+RIGHT ARROW will attempt to complete what you have already typed automatically. If the partial feature name you type matches more than one feature for the current context, the
vcgrfListMembers 0 list members window will be displayed where the appropriate selection can be made.
Please see the vxurfCodeTextEditorWindow 0 core Visual Studio .NET editor
vcgrfListMembers 0 List Members for more information and additional ways to access this feature.
quick_info
2 Quick Info
When browsing or editing a
/20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlclass class text the editor provides quick, context-sensitive information about the current
/20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlclass class . This allows the developer to quickly get summary information about a particular
/20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlfeature feature such as the name,
/20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlargument argument parameters, return type and usage description at a glance. Quick Info will also show detailed information for any /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlpreconditions *preconditions and /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xmlpostconditions *postconditions applied to the feature. To display the Quick Info simply move the mouse cursor over the feature in question and a tooltip will display the information regarding the feature.
Please see the vxurfCodeTextEditorWindow 0 core Visual Studio .NET editor
vcgrfQuickInfo 0 Quick Info for more information and ways to access this feature.
parameter_info
2 Parameter Info
The Parameter Info option opens the Parameters list to give you information about the number, names, and types of parameters required by a function or attribute. Parameter Info is similar to the Eiffel editor's urlQuick Info in the respect it shows associated feature's full information and description. The difference between these two features is the parameter information will highlight the next parameter, in the description of the feature, by making the parameter bold.
Please see the vxurfCodeTextEditorWindow 0 core Visual Studio .NET editor
vcgrfParameterInfo 0 Parameter Info for more information and ways to access this feature.
auto_brace_matching
2 Automatic Brace Matching
Automatic brace matching gives you immediate feedback on misplaced brackets or open-ended code segments. This feature is always in effect; there is no related menu command or other option to disable it.
Automatic brace matching recognizes the following pairs:
400 0
( ) Parentheses
[ ] Brackets
{ } Braces
<< >> Array angled brackets
Language constructs, such as do...end and if...then...end, are also automatically matched.
